sections.title: Dental fillings
sections.body:
Fillings are one of the most common dental treatments — but when they’re done well, they’re anything but routine.

A filling is used to repair a tooth that’s been damaged by decay, wear, or fracture, helping to restore its strength and function while preventing further problems.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, we approach fillings conservatively and carefully, with an emphasis on longevity rather than quick fixes.
bullets: Conservative repair of decay, wear, or fracture
Materials matched to tooth and bite
Careful shaping for comfort and function

sections.title: Our approach to fillings
items: We preserve as much natural tooth as possible
Materials are chosen to suit the tooth and bite
Fillings are shaped carefully so they function properly
Comfort and cleanability are considered from the start
We explain the options and any alternatives clearly

sections.title: Types of filling materials
sections.body:
There are different materials available, and the right choice depends on the tooth, its position, and how much load it takes.

We’ll explain the advantages and limitations of each option, how visible the filling may be, how durable it’s likely to be, and any alternatives worth considering.
bullets: We match material choice to the tooth and bite
We discuss appearance and durability clearly
We explain any alternatives where relevant

sections.title: When a filling is needed
items: Decay has weakened part of a tooth
An old filling has failed or leaked
A tooth has chipped or worn down
Monitoring versus intervention is discussed where appropriate

sections.title: What to expect during treatment
sections.strapline: Placing a filling is usually straightforward.

sections.title: Comfort and aftercare
items: Mild sensitivity for a short time is normal
We’ll explain what to expect after treatment
We’ll advise how to care for the tooth
Let us know if something doesn’t feel right

sections.title: When a filling may not be enough
sections.body:
Sometimes a filling isn’t the best long-term solution, particularly if a tooth is heavily weakened.

In those cases, we may discuss alternatives such as crowns or onlays, explaining the reasons clearly so you understand the trade-offs involved.
bullets: We explain when a crown or onlay may be safer
We discuss trade-offs so you can decide confidently

sections.title: When a filling needs extra support
sections.body: If the tooth is heavily broken down or the nerve is affected, we guide you through the next restorative steps.

sections.title: Keeping the restored tooth healthy
sections.body: Regular hygiene visits and gum care keep the margins clean and reduce the risk of future decay around a filling. We plan maintenance intervals based on your gum health and any bruxism or diet risks.
bullets: Hygiene and gum care to protect the edges
Monitoring for cracks, leakage, or wear
Occlusal splints for clenching or grinding
Check-ups to time replacements before problems escalate
Advice on diet and home care around restorations

faqs.question: When is amalgam better than composite?
faqs.answer: We consider amalgam when the tooth takes heavy load, when isolation is difficult, or when longevity is the priority. We bond amalgams to enhance strength and seal.

faqs.question: How long will sensitivity last?
faqs.answer: Mild temperature or bite sensitivity can last a few days. Let us know if it persists beyond a week or if pain wakes you at night.

faqs.question: What happens during the appointment?
faqs.answer: We numb the tooth, isolate it, remove decay or failing material, bond the new filling, shape and polish it, and check the bite before you leave.

faqs.question: When do you recommend an onlay or crown?
faqs.answer: If too much tooth is missing for a filling to hold safely, we may plan an onlay or crown to reinforce the structure and seal the tooth.
